text.content: Study the Uniswap V2 Contract Source Code with Me - Core

title.plain_text: Study the Uniswap V2 Contract Source Code with Me - Core

title: Study the Uniswap V2 Contract Source Code with Me - Core
today weâ€™ll study the Uniswap core contract.
the project structure is also very simple:
thereâ€™s only three contracts to look into
UniswapV2ERC20
c
UniswapV2Factory
c
and
UniswapV2Pair
c
i recall in the library file of pheriphery, it has interacted with
UniswapV2Factory
c
's
createPair
c
and
UniswapV2Pair
c
's
swap
c
and so on
at first i thought only the
Router
c
are allowed to invoke the factory and the pair contract, it turns out that i am wrong, it turns out anyone can invoke it, making a
Router
c
just saves user from repeating approve the lp token address
this is a factory contract to create the pair contract, i.e. the lp token contract, it is not only an erc20, but also has logic to handle swapping and liquidity
right now, i have not much idea about
feeTo
c
and
feeToSetter
c
, but i think it has something to do with pair contract
getPair
c
is a mapping that index the lp address and token addresses
allPairs
c
is an array storing all the pairs
thereâ€™s also an event which i believe will be emitted by the
createPair
c
function
thereâ€™s also a function that returns the pair length
and there are two trivial setters that are put in the end, and only the
feeToSetter
c
are allowed to set it
i think overall the logic is very easy to understand, the only confusing part for me is
create2
c
this is to make sure the lp token can be precomputed using this
method
a
https://docs.soliditylang.org/en/v0.8.11/control-structures.html#salted-contract-creations-create2
which can be seen in the library of
Router02
c
n
c
should be the length of the init code, and it is
mload(bytecode)
c
, which loads the first word
my guess here is that the first word (32 bytes) of the
bytecode
c
is the length of the initcode, then itâ€™s followed by the actual code
v
c
is the wei sent to the new address
s
c
is the
bytes32
c
that is used to replace nonce i think
this is the base of the lp pair contract, which is a erc20 and uses eip712 standard
the motivation os using EIP712 is to enable offchain signing in order to reduce the number of transaction
i think this should not be the focus of this article (it should be extended to another topic), letâ€™s just focus on main logic here
this is the real core of uniswap v2
the most important variable is
reserve0
c
and
reserve1
c
, as their product will be a constant
k
c
in order to keep the balance of
token0
c
and
token1
c
to be the same
you might wonder why
reserve
c
and
blockTimestampLast
c
uses weird
uint
c
, i think this is just to pack them up into one word (32 bytes) in EVM storage so that it could be more storage efficient
and there is a
lock
c
modifier to prevent reentrancy, all the critical state changing external function needs to be wrapped with that
after reading some code, the
kLast
c
here is only useful when the factory has set the
feeTo
c
address (as it need to log down the actually k substracting the fee), otherwise it will be zero
this will just called by the factory and
initilaize
c
limit the sender should only be the
factory
c
_update
c
is responsible for updating the state such as
reserve
c
and
priceCumulativeLast
c
_mintFee
c
will mint the fee of lp token set by the factory
this is the core logic of contract minting

i think one problem with this logic is that if the user directly sent their token to the lp pair contract without minting the lp token at the same time, their IOU might go to the next user who used to router, so thatâ€™s why we should never directly interact with lp token contract
last core function of the lp, that is swapping
Make sure the state is up-to-date
anyone can make a profit here if they find out the
balance
c
is more than
reserve
c
i remember sam wrote an article about someone accidentally transfer the token to the lp, so he discover that anyone could call this
skim
c
function to get back the token, but unfortunately it is front run by someone else
